articles.headline: Obama Proposes a First Overhaul of Finance Rules
articles.snippet: The proposal would require credit-default swaps and other types of derivative contracts to be traded on exchanges and backed by capital reserves.
articles.abstract: The proposal would require credit-default swaps and other types of derivative contracts to be traded on exchanges and backed by capital reserves.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  In its first detailed effort to overhaul financial regulations, the Obama administration on Wednesday sought new authority over the complex financial instruments, known as derivatives, that were a major cause of the financial crisis and have gone largely unregulated for decades.
articles.byline: By Stephen Labaton and Jackie Calmes

articles.headline: Under Pressure, Craigslist to Remove ‘Erotic’ Ads
articles.snippet: Starting next Wednesday, the category will be called “adult services,” and employees will be hired to monitor it for illicit content. Attorneys general in several states are skeptical.
articles.abstract: Starting next Wednesday, the category will be called “adult services,” and employees will be hired to monitor it for illicit content. Attorneys general in several states are skeptical.
articles.lead_paragraph: Craigslist, the Web’s largest classified advertising site, said on Wednesday that it would close its erotic services category, which critics have said is a forum that fosters prostitution and other illegal activities.

articles.headline: Thriving Norway Provides an Economics Lesson
articles.snippet: Instead of spending its oil riches, Norway saved, and it is now growing in the midst of the global recession.
articles.abstract: Instead of spending its oil riches, Norway saved, and it is now growing in the midst of the global recession.
articles.lead_paragraph: OSLO  When capitalism seemed on the verge of collapse last fall, Kristin Halvorsen, Norway’s Socialist finance minister and a longtime free market skeptic, did more than crow.

articles.headline: Decoding the Hype on Gadgets
articles.snippet: Consumer tech companies revel in misdirected marketing of their products. Here are a few ways to determine what’s really important among features.
articles.abstract: Consumer tech companies revel in misdirected marketing of their products. Here are a few ways to determine what’s really important among features.
articles.lead_paragraph: There are all kinds of things that make the consumer-technology industry unusual. For example, as power, speed and features keep going up, electronics prices keep going down, year after year. In what other industry does that happen?

articles.headline: Trial Puts Spotlight on Merck
articles.snippet: A class-action lawsuit over the strategies that Merck used to market its painkiller Vioxx in Australia is earning the American drug maker some bad publicity.
articles.abstract: A class-action lawsuit over the strategies that Merck used to market its painkiller Vioxx in Australia is earning the American drug maker some bad publicity.
articles.lead_paragraph: Australians have been riveted over the last month by a class-action lawsuit that is pulling back the curtain on strategies that the American drug giant Merck used in its international marketing of the painkiller Vioxx.

articles.headline: A Ruling Against Intel, Unlikely to Drag It Down
articles.snippet: A.M.D. cheered the European ruling, but the history of antitrust cases against big technology companies suggests that little will change in the marketplace.
articles.abstract: A.M.D. cheered the European ruling, but the history of antitrust cases against big technology companies suggests that little will change in the marketplace.
articles.lead_paragraph: European regulators have spent close to nine years investigating whether Intel, the world’s largest chip maker, illegally hampered competitors in its dealings with computer makers and retailers. And on Wednesday, they finally reached a conclusion, punishing Intel with a record fine of 1.06 billion euros ($1.45 billion) for abusing its dominant position in the computer chip market.

articles.headline: Slow Start to U.S. Plan for Modifying Mortgages
articles.snippet: Two months into a plan to help homeowners avoid foreclosure, only about 55,000 have enrolled.
articles.abstract: Two months into a plan to help homeowners avoid foreclosure, only about 55,000 have enrolled.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration’s plan to help millions of troubled homeowners avoid foreclosure by reducing the size of their mortgage payments is just getting off the ground.

articles.headline: Scouts Train to Fight Terrorists, and More
articles.snippet: An affiliate of the Boy Scouts of America is training young people to confront terrorism and border security.
articles.abstract: An affiliate of the Boy Scouts of America is training young people to confront terrorism and border security.
articles.lead_paragraph: IMPERIAL, Calif.  Ten minutes into arrant mayhem in this town near the Mexican border, and the gunman, a disgruntled Iraq war veteran, has already taken out two people, one slumped in his desk, the other covered in blood on the floor.

articles.headline: Obama Moves to Bar Release of Detainee Abuse Photos
articles.snippet: President Obama cited concerns that the photos of U.S. military personnel abusing prisoners in Iraq and Afghanistan could further antagonize enemies.
articles.abstract: President Obama cited concerns that the photos of U.S. military personnel abusing prisoners in Iraq and Afghanistan could further antagonize enemies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama said Wednesday that he would fight to prevent the release of photographs documenting abuse of prisoners in Iraq and Afghanistan by United States military personnel, reversing his position on the issue after commanders warned that the images could set off a deadly backlash against American troops.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Thom Shanker

articles.headline: Chrysler Plans to Shut 1 in 4 of Its U.S. Dealers
articles.snippet: The carmaker sent letters to 789 of its 3,200 American dealers revoking their franchises.
articles.abstract: The carmaker sent letters to 789 of its 3,200 American dealers revoking their franchises.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  The historic downsizing of the American auto industry swept through new-car showrooms on Thursday, as dealers across the country, from Fuller Jeep in Rockland, Me., to Island Dodge in Hawaii, learned that they would be forced to close their doors.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Nick Bunkley
